Review Unveiling complexities: Reviews on insights into the mechanism of oxygen evolution reaction Pengxiang Zhang a Jiawen Wang a Tianyu Yang a Ruizhe Wang a Ruofan Shen a Zhikun Peng a Yanyan Liu b * Xianli Wu a * Jianchun Jiang c Baojun Li a * a College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China College of Chemistry Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou Henan 450001 China College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China b College of Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou 450002, Henan, China College of Science Henan Agricultural University Zhengzhou Henan 450002 China College of Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou 450002, Henan, China c Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, CAF, National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Chemical Utilization, Key and Open Laboratory on Forest Chemical Engineering, SFA, Nanjing 210042, Jiangsu, China Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products CAF National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Chemical Utilization Key and Open Laboratory on Forest Chemical Engineering SFA Nanjing Jiangsu 210042 China Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, CAF, National Engineering Laboratory for Biomass Chemical Utilization, Key and Open Laboratory on Forest Chemical Engineering, SFA, Nanjing 210042, Jiangsu, China * Corresponding author. The study of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) mechanism is vital for advancing our understanding of this pivotal energy conversion process. This review synthesizes recent advancements in OER mechanism, emphasizing the intricate relationship between catalytic mechanisms and catalyst design. This review discusses the connotation and cutting-edge progress of traditional mechanisms such as adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) and lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) as well as emerging pathways including oxide path mechanism (OPM), oxo-oxo coupling mechanism (OCM), and intramolecular oxygen coupling mechanism (IMOC) etc. Innovative research progress on the coexistence and transformation of multiple mechanisms is highlighted, and the intrinsic factors that influence these dynamic processes are summarized. Advanced characterization techniques and theoretical modeling are underscored as indispensable tools for revealing these complex interactions. This review provides guiding principles for mechanism-based catalyst design. Finally, in view of the multidimensional challenges currently faced by OER mechanisms, prospects for future research are given to bridge the gap between mechanism innovation and experimental verification and application. This comprehensive review provides valuable perspectives for advancing clean energy technologies and achieving sustainable development. Graphical Abstract This review systematically explores the evolution of OER mechanisms, including traditional and emerging pathways, highlights dynamic coexistence and transitions, and provides guiding principles for catalyst design, advancing clean energy research. Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction Catalytic mechanism Catalyst design Adsorption evolution mechanism Lattice oxygen mechanism 1 Introduction In the context of global energy transition and environmental sustainability, the study of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) holds immense significance [1,2]. Because OER is a fundamental electrochemical process for a range of clean energy technologies including oxygen production, metal-air batteries, fuel cells, and water electrolysis [3]. These technologies are essential for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and achieving carbon neutrality. By facilitating efficient energy conversion and storage, OER plays a pivotal role in addressing the pressing challenges of climate change and resource depletion. A comprehensive understanding of OER mechanisms, along with the development of highly efficient catalysts, is crucial for enhancing the performance of these energy devices. This fosters a cleaner and more sustainable energy landscape, driving the global shift towards renewable energy sources and innovative energy solutions [4]. The centrality of OER to the energy transition underscores the criticality of elucidating its intricate mechanism [5]. Delving into the fundamental processes that govern OER and understanding how catalysts facilitate these processes are imperative for designing and developing efficient and sustainable energy conversion systems. This mechanistic exploration encompasses the sequential adsorption and activation of water molecules, the oxidative transformation of water into oxygen, and the subsequent release of oxygen gas concomitant with electron transfer [6]. The catalytic landscape of OER is equally enthralling. Over the past decades, researchers have embarked on a quest to harness the catalytic prowess of materials ranging from transition metal oxides and complex oxides to metal alloys and two-dimensional nanomaterials [7,8]. Catalytic design strategies have transcended conventional paradigms, extending to the meticulous manipulation of crystal structures, surface active sites, and electronic conductivity [9]. The interplay of these factors has contributed to the enhancement of catalytic performance with the ultimate objective of reducing the thermodynamic and kinetic barriers associated with OER. Furthermore, innovative approaches such as doping, surface modification, and the integration of emerging nanomaterials have heralded promising avenues for catalytic advancement [10]. 1.1 Research dynamic analysis of OER mechanism The field of OER research has shown substantial growth over the past decade, reflecting its significance in renewable energy systems such as water splitting, metal-air batteries, and electrochemical synthesis. Analysis of publication trends (Fig. 1(a) ) reveals a sharp increase in the number of OER-related papers since 2012, with over 4000 articles published annually by 2024. Although studies focusing on the fundamental “Mechanism” of OER account for a smaller fraction of the total, their consistent growth highlights the increasing emphasis on understanding catalytic processes at a deeper level. This mechanism focus is crucial for advancing catalyst design principles, enabling breakthroughs in efficiency and sustainability. In Fig. 1(b), the publication trends comparing AEM and LOM indicate a paradigm shift. Since 2022, research on lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) has accelerated, surpassing AEM by 2024, which underscores the increasing interest in leveraging lattice oxygen dynamics. This reflects the potential of LOM to unlock superior catalytic activities by bypassing traditional mechanistic limitations. The keyword co-occurrence network in Fig. 1(c) highlights the diversity and complexity of research hotspots in the OER domain. Key themes include catalyst development (e.g., nanosheets, layered double hydroxides), mechanistic investigations (e.g., surface reconstruction, adsorption dynamics), and stability challenges associated with materials such as nickel and cobalt oxides. The emergence of lattice oxygen as a focal point is indicative of growing efforts to integrate unconventional pathways into catalyst design strategies. Fig. 1(d) further illustrates the evolving landscape of OER research by linking keywords to specific temporal trends. Early emphasis on foundational properties like anion exchange membrane, stability and material design has given way to cutting-edge themes such as advanced mechanisms and their implications for scalability and performance. Over time, the focus has shifted toward more mechanism insights into AEM, LOM, and related phenomena. Recent research explores advanced materials like metal oxides and perovskites while incorporating novel pathways such as lattice oxygen activation. This evolution highlights the growing interest in the relationship between catalytic sites and mechanisms. 1.2 Existing review analysis In the dynamic field of OER research, numerous reviews have focused on various dimensions, including catalyst design, mechanistic insights, and experimental methodologies. For instance, studies on specific catalyst classes, such as non-precious metals [11,12], carbon-based non-metals [1], transition metal nitrides [13], highlight their design principles and application challenges. Reviews on materials derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOF) [3] offer a perspective on precursor engineering, while spin-state transitions in OER [14] present a unique focus on the electronic structure’s role in activity modulation. Catalyst surface reconstruction and active site recognition [10,15], multifunctional catalysts integrating OER and HER [8,16] have also attracted attention. Mechanistic reviews delve into traditional theories, such as the AEM and LOM [4], while others emphasize the transformative potential of advanced techniques [9,17]. Furthermore, these reviews often treat OER mechanisms as static frameworks, omitting the dynamic interplay and potential coexistence of multiple mechanisms under varying conditions. More importantly, emerging models like the oxide path mechanism (OPM) and oxygen coupling mechanism (OCM) have not been systematically integrated with traditional theories. 1.3 Main purpose and content of this review While numerous papers have explored the OER mechanisms, this review stands out by offering a holistic and integrative perspective that bridges established theories and emerging advancements. Unlike earlier works that often focus on a single mechanism or a specific class of catalysts, this review systematically examines multiple OER mechanisms, including traditional frameworks like the AEM and LOM, alongside newer concepts, such as the OPM and OCM. Additionally, this review emphasizes the coexistence and interconversion of these mechanisms in practical catalytic processes, a new dimension that has received little attention. Beyond mechanism elucidation, this work delves into mechanism-guided catalyst design and especially, highlight the strategies, such as defect engineering, surface reconstruction, and interface modulation. By integrating advanced characterization techniques, theoretical modeling and experimental evidence, this article offers actionable insights for researchers to optimize catalyst performance and stability. This comprehensive and forward-looking approach positions this review as a pivotal resource for advancing OER research and fostering innovations in sustainable energy technologies. 2 Fundamental Electrochemistry of OER 2.1 AEM Eliciting the intricacies of the OER is fundamental to the targeted advancement of electrocatalysts. The conventional OER paradigm involves a sequence of four progressive electron transfer stages, each associated with the transient formation of key oxygenated species: hydroxyl (OH*), oxide (O*), and peroxide (OOH*). The exhalation of O2 into the surrounding medium from the catalyst surface denotes the fruition of the OER cycle [18]. The traditional OER process under acidic conditions (Fig. 2(a) ): (1) H2O + * → OH* + H+ + e– (2) OH* → O* + H+ + e– (3) H2O + O* → OOH* + H+ + e– (4) OOH* → O2*+H+ + e– (5) O2* → O2 + * (6) Overall: 2H2O → 4H+ + O2 + 4e– The traditional OER process under alkaline conditions (Fig. 2(b)): (7) OH– + * → OH* + e– (8) OH* + OH– → H2O+O* + e– (9) O* + OH– → OOH* + e– (10) OOH* + OH–→ O2* + H2O+ e– (11) O2* → O2 + * (12) Overall: 4OH– → 2H2O + O2 + 4e– AEM relies on metals as adsorption sites that are frequently oxidized and reduced during the reaction. In this mechanism, catalytic activity is closely linked to the ability of the metal to cycle between different oxidation states, thereby facilitating the adsorption and desorption of key reaction intermediates. The efficiency of AEM is influenced by the electronic properties of the metal, in particular its ability to form strong metal-oxygen bonds, which are critical for stabilizing high-energy intermediates. In addition, the surface structure of the metal plays an important role in AEM. Well-defined surface facets and defects can provide active sites with unique geometries that favor specific adsorption modes and reaction pathways. In summary, AEM in OER are a complex interplay of metal redox chemistry, surface structure, and electronic interactions. It is important to emphasize that these steps constitute the traditional AEM mechanism. Subsequent studies have proposed alternative mechanisms based on different catalyst compositions and reaction conditions, but all studies (including LOM) are based on these basic steps and the key roles of related intermediates. 2.2 Lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) Meffoed et al. [19] and Grimaud et al. [20] proposed and experimentally verified that lattice oxygen in some transition metal oxides can be activated for OER process and named this process LOM [19,20]. The LOM represents a transformative approach to understanding OER, where lattice oxygen within the catalyst directly contributes to oxygen molecule generation. This mechanism contrasts with traditional adsorption-based pathways like the AEM and provides new opportunities to enhance catalytic activity and stability. LOM often involves lattice oxygen oxidation, the release of oxygen molecules, and subsequent regeneration of lattice oxygen to sustain the catalytic cycle. Its versatility arises from the variety of active site configurations observed, which include oxygen vacancies, single-metal centers, and dual-metal sites. Within the LOM framework, oxygen vacancies play a critical role in the oxygen vacancy site mechanism (OVSM), where lattice oxygen serves as the primary reactive species (Fig. 3(a) ). These vacancies facilitate the activation and release of lattice oxygen as molecular oxygen, making OVSM especially relevant in transition metal oxides with high oxygen defect densities. Alternatively, in the single metal site mechanism (SMSM), lattice oxygen plays a supporting role as the adjacent metal center drives the catalytic process (Fig. 3(b)). This configuration is common in systems where isolated active metal sites enhance selectivity and minimize competing reactions. A more collaborative dynamic of LOM emerges as dual-metal site mechanism (DMSM), in which two adjacent metal sites work synergistically with lattice oxygen, significantly improving catalytic efficiency through shared electronic and geometric contributions (Fig. 3(c)) [21]. Thus, SMSM excels in materials dominated by single oxygen vacancies, while DMSM favors catalysts that rely on extensive oxygen network participation. This nuanced understanding of LOM broadens the scope of catalyst design strategies and emphasizes the importance of tailoring oxygen vacancies, optimizing metal coordination, and utilizing multi-metal systems. By integrating these insights, researchers can engineer catalysts that can not only exhibit higher activity but also maintain durability under operational conditions. 2.3 Unconventional mechanisms Some new catalytic mechanism models based on existing knowledge have been proposed for OER [19,22], including the [23–25], OPM [26], intramolecular oxygen coupling (IMOC) mechanism, water nucleophilic attack (WNA) mechanism and oxo-oxo coupling mechanism (OCM), which emphasize the direct coupling of O-O to generate oxygen during the catalytic process [23,27]. The OPM facilitates the direct coupling of O-O radicals, distinct from the LOM mechanism, as it does not entail the activation or evolution of lattice oxygen (Fig. 4(a) ). In the OPM, the intermediates are exclusively *O and *OH. This mechanism imposes strict requirements on the geometric configuration of metal active sites, particularly the atomic arrangement and spacing of dual-metal centers. Intriguingly, the IMOC mechanism parallels the OPM, in a focus on intramolecular coupling steps (Fig. 4(b)). This association typically reflects unique structural configurations, such as metal-ligand complexes or highly specialized active sites, which depend on the optimization of molecular coordination to achieve effective coupling [23,24,28]. Furthermore, an alternative pathway related to IMOC is the WNA, which involves a direct nucleophilic assault on water to liberate O2 and rejuvenate the catalyst. The WNA mechanism, which often manifests on specific catalyst surfaces, underscores the pivotal role of water molecules in the reaction process. The OCM is an emerging concept in the field of OER catalysis over single atom catalysts (SACs). Compared with OPM and LOM, OCM emphasizes the importance of single metal sites within SACs, as these mechanisms require an oxide framework with high oxygen density to activate oxygen. OCM emphasizes the key role of dispersed single metal sites in promoting direct O*-O* radical connections, thereby accelerating the oxygen release process [29]. In addition, specific catalyst structures have been proposed recently. For example, dual-site synergistic catalytic mechanism (DSSM) focuses on the synergistic effect of two different catalytic centers [30]. The multi-hole mechanism observed in α-Fe2O3 emphasizes the contribution of multiple active sites or oxygen vacancies to the enhanced catalytic activity [31]. These models provide new insights into the complex OER pathway and guide innovative strategies for catalyst design [25]. The study of dynamic switching of catalytic mechanisms allows us to understand the diversity and complexity of OER reactions better, providing a more precise theoretical basis for the design and development of efficient OER catalysts. 2.4 Band theory insights into AEM and LOM mechanisms The characteristics of AEM and LOM mechanisms are as described previously. Band theory is often used to analyze the traditional catalytic mechanism of OER to illustrate the difference between AEM and LOM [32]. The bond band with oxygen characteristics is generally represented by (M-O). Due to in-situ electron repulsion within the d orbital, the antibonding band will split into the empty upper Hubbard band (UHB) and the filled lower Hubbard band (LHB) [33]. For the traditional AEM route, the LHB is near the Fermi level, and electrons are transferred from the LHB orbit to the OER reaction process (Fig. 5(a) ) [34]. In the LOM route, the non-bonded oxygen band (ONB) is near the Fermi level, and electrons are transferred from the ONB to the OER reaction process (Fig. 5(b)). Obviously, changes in the oxidation state of the metal are involved when metal serves as a redox center and the valence state of metal does not vary when lattice oxygen serves as a redox center. 3 Mechanism insights of OER As a complex multi-step catalytic reaction, the exploration of OER has rapidly expanded our understanding of the catalytic mechanism and reaction process [14]. The AEM focuses on the adsorption and evolution of reaction intermediates on metal sites in catalysts, involving the oxidation and reduction of metals [10,35]. LOM emphasizes the critical role of oxygen atoms within the crystal lattice of catalyst materials, involving the transition of different oxidation states [4,36,37]. However, with the deepening of scientific research, researchers are re-examining and expanding our understanding of catalytic mechanisms from multiple dimensions [38]. This chapter will outline the evolution from traditional catalytic mechanisms to newly proposed catalytic mechanisms based on the latest understanding, as well as catalytic mechanisms that are dynamically switched during catalytic reactions, thus providing a comprehensive background for in-depth exploration of the catalytic mechanism of OER. 3.1 AEM At the core of AEM lies the adsorption of oxygen intermediates, often in forms such as O* or OH* on active sites of the catalyst surface [39]. This step is pivotal as it involves electron transfer and changes in binding energies at the interface between the catalyst surface and the intermediates, directly influencing the catalytic activity of OER. Subsequently, AEM encompasses further oxidation steps, during which the oxygen intermediates transform their adsorbed states to more stable oxygen gas by accepting electrons. This oxidation step often involves complex interactions and electron transfers among multiple intermediates, adding a layer of complexity to the reaction kinetics. Finally, the oxygen evolution stage within AEM signifies the formation and desorption of oxygen gas, marking the completion of the OER cycle. In the context of catalysis following the AEM for OER, there is an energy scaling relationship between the *OH and *OOH intermediates, where the binding energies of these intermediates exhibit linear correlation and adhere to a scaling relation of ΔG OOH = ΔG OH + 3.2 ± 0.2 eV [40]. Tuning the binding energy of each intermediate independently is a challenging endeavor, but it frequently leads to OER overpotentials that surpass the specified limit of 370 mV imposed by AEM [41]. Recent advancements have demonstrated that catalyst structural transformations, including doping, electronic modulation, and defect engineering, can effectively modulate the binding of oxygen intermediates, thereby reducing the energy barriers associated with AEM. This phenomenon may be attributed to the precise design of catalysts that alter the OER pathway, breaking the linear relationship between *OH and *OOH [42]. For instance, Peng et al. [43] demonstrated enhanced activity and stability of AEM in acidic OER by preparing robust Ru-W oxide intermixed heterostructures (Ru-W)O x through rapid oxidation and metal-thermal migration processes (Fig. 6(a) ). The study revealed that preferential oxidation of W species in the intermixed heterostructure and valence state oscillations at Ru sites significantly stabilized the asymmetric Ru-O-W active units on the oxidized tungsten substrate (Fig. 6(b)). The introduction of high-valent W species alleviated the distortion of octahedral RuO6 structural units during OER process, reducing Ru-O bond lengths and promoting orbital overlap, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity dominated by AEM (Figs. 6(c) and (d)). The abundant W-O-Ru functional units in (Ru-W)O x effectively modified the electronic structure of Ru by increasing electron density, optimizing the bond strength between intermediate oxygen species and Ru sites, ultimately enhancing both stability and intrinsic activity (Fig. 6(e)) . Theoretical calculations demonstrated that Ru-O-W units played a critical role in mediating the absorption of OH*, O*, and the dissociation of OOH*. Compared to RuO x and WO3, (Ru-W)O x exhibits a lower energy barrier to overcome in rate-determining step (RDS) (*O to *OOH) (Fig. 6(f)). These findings underscore the potential of catalyst design to reduce overpotentials in OER by manipulating the binding of oxygen intermediates and optimizing the catalytic pathway, even in the context of AEM. Liu et al. [44] designed a series of single 3d transition metal atom catalysts co-doped with MoS2 (3d-TMO6@MoS2), encompassing hexacoordinate structures (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, and Co) and tricoordinate structures (TM = Ni, Cu, and Zn). The study revealed that hexacoordinate structures spontaneously transitioned into tetracoordinate structures (Fig. 6(g)) during OER. This dynamic catalytic mechanism exposed active sites and optimized the strength of metal-oxygen bonds. Remarkably, the FeO6@MoS2 catalyst exhibited exceptional activity and structural stability. Building upon the traditional AEM, the research proposed a dynamic adsorbate evolution mechanism (DAEM) (Fig. 6(h) and (i)). According to this mechanism, as oxygen species (OH*/O*/OOH*) being adsorbed, active transition metals migrate from hexacoordinate positions to tetracoordinate positions and return to hexacoordinate positions after oxygen desorption. This discovery provides a novel theoretical foundation for the enhancement of AEM of OER. 3.2 LOM The LOM, introduced by Mefford and Grimaud, has garnered extensive scholarly attention. Here, the oxygen band near the Fermi level is crucial, serving as the central redox agent in the OER process. This discovery has shifted the research focus towards the role of lattice oxygen in catalysis. In the initial deprotonation step of LOM, hydrogen-oxygen bonds are broken, resulting in the ionization of hydrogen. Simultaneously, adsorbed OH- are transformed into O2–. Subsequent electron transfer processes convert O2– into O–, facilitating the coupling of O–O bonds. This O–O coupling step involves chemical reactions between non-bonding oxygen states located between oxygen ions. The formation of O2 necessitates the removal of two electrons from the oxygen orbitals of (O–O)2–. Unlike AEM, LOM engages in oxygen-oxygen redox chemistry. This capability enables LOM to directly form O–O bonds, bypassing the rate-determining step of O–O bond formation in AEM. This inherent advantage highlights the superior OER activity of LOM-based catalysts compared to their AEM counterparts [45]. A widely adopted strategy for inducing LOM pathways involves heterometal doping to enhance the valence state and charge density of catalytic metal cation sites, introduce lattice strain, and create oxygen vacancies. These modifications alter the electronic structure and facilitate lattice oxygen participation in the OER process [46–48]. Despite these advancements, achieving precise control over a single LOM pathway remains a significant challenge. The coexistence of multiple LOMs within a catalyst can complicate the optimization of activity and stability, emphasizing the need for further research into tailoring catalyst structures to selectively activate specific LOM pathways. Recently, the study from Huang et al. [49] represents a significant step in understanding how oxygen defect engineering can selectively activate specific OER mechanisms in NiFe-layered double hydroxide (NiFe-LDH)/FeOOH heterostructures (Figs. 7(a) and (b) ), such as single lattice oxygen mechanism (sLOM, similar to SMSM pathway of LOM), while avoiding double single lattice oxygen mechanism (dLOM, similar to DMSM pathway of LOM). By employing oxygen defect engineering, the authors demonstrate that it is possible to fine-tune catalytic activity and selectively favor the sLOM, as evidenced by DEMS measurements. This study contributes to the broader effort of tailoring OER pathways by exploiting structural and electronic properties at the atomic level. However, current OER research still lacks a clearer explanation for the selective triggering of a single pathway among multiple LOM pathways and the exclusion of other pathways. The dominance and inhibition of SMSM and DMSM pathways in the LOM mechanism and their advantages and disadvantages in application still need to be further studied by researchers to enhance the relevant understanding [52]. Transition metal oxides (hydroxides) have garnered extensive research interest as catalysts for LOM in OER due to their high catalytic activity and robust stability [53]. Recent studies have indicated that modulating the lattice oxygen activity is an effective strategy for enhancing the activity of transition metal oxides or (oxy)hydroxide electrocatalysts [54,55]. Chen et al. [49] reported a sacrificial-template-directed method for synthesizing Mo-doped ultra-thin NiFe-based (oxy)hydroxide catalysts. DFT calculations revealed that MoNiFe (oxy)hydroxide possesses enhanced lattice oxygen activity, manifested as weakened metal-oxygen bonds, an upward shift of O 2p centers relative to the Fermi level, and a reduction in the formation energy of oxygen vacancies (Figs. 7(c) and (d)). Compared to NiFe (oxy)hydroxide, MoNiFe (oxy)hydroxide exhibited higher local density of states around oxygen ligands, elevated metal oxidation states, and delayed cation electrochemical redox processes. This activation of lattice oxygen effectively shifts the potential-determining step from oxygen vacancy formation in NiFe (oxy)hydroxide to the *OOH deprotonation process in MoNiFe (oxy)hydroxide, significantly enhancing its intrinsic OER activity. Defects represent another crucial factor influencing LOM [56]. Shao et al. [50] explored the potential role of LOM in OER electrocatalysis. It was found that introducing Sr defects at A-sites of LaSr perovskite catalysts led to improved OER performance and enhanced specific activity (Fig. 7(e)). Notably, the intrinsic OER activity exhibited a strong correlation with oxygen ion diffusion rates. The introduction of appropriate A-site cation defects, which solely altered the oxygen vacancy content, unequivocally demonstrated the significant role of LOM (Fig. 7(f)). By introducing A-site Sr defects, an increased number of oxygen vacancies were generated, resulting in a substantial enhancement of bulk oxygen migration rates. This facilitated rapid replenishment of active lattice oxygen sites during the evolution process, thereby improving the OER performance according to the LOM mechanism. Importantly, this alteration did not affect the material’s crystal structure and/or electronic structure. The results provide robust evidence for the strong correlation between OER activity and oxygen ion diffusion rates, supporting the pivotal role of lattice oxygen in promoting OER on perovskite catalysts employing the LOM scheme. It is essential to note that the involvement of lattice oxygen often leads to the formation of soluble high-valence oxygen vacancy intermediates, triggering catalyst structure collapse and dissolution, subsequently resulting in a sharp decrease in catalytic activity, making stability challenging to maintain. Luo et al. [51] addressed this challenge by anchoring Ru oxide species onto UiO-67-bpydc through Ru–N bonds, synthesizing atomically dispersed Ru oxide catalysts for efficient OER in acidic conditions. Chemical probe mechanism verification demonstrated that the Ru-N bonds between Ru oxide species and UiO-67-bpydc not only facilitated the participation of lattice oxygen in OER process but also stabilized soluble *Vo-RuO4 intermediates, ensuring long-term stability (Figs. 7(g) and (h)). Computational analysis confirmed that the Ru-N bonds in *Vo-RuO4-Ru-UiO-67-bpydc were more stable than the Ru-O bonds in *Vo-RuO4-RuO2, thereby enhancing OER stability. Furthermore, the adsorption energy of *OOH on Ru-UiO-67-bpydc was lower than that on RuO2. Investigation into the reaction pathways of Ru-UiO-67-bpydc and RuO2 revealed that the desorption of *O2 2– was the RDS in acidic OER for Ru-UiO-67-bpydc, distinct from RuO2. As the lattice Ru-O bonds were activated, the energy barrier from *O to *O2 2– was reduced, causing a shift in the RDS and enhancing the kinetics of acidic OER (Figs. 7(i)–(l)). The profound implications of LOM transcend the confines of any single catalytic material. Its pertinence extends across a spectrum of materials, including transition metal oxides, perovskites, and complex metal oxides, where lattice oxygen’s versatile engagement drives the pursuit of tailored OER catalysts. Fine-tuning material properties, ranging from crystallographic arrangements to the manipulation of defect sites and electronic configurations, emerges as a strategic imperative in the relentless quest for elevated OER performance. In summation, LOM serves as a beacon illuminating the intricate OER landscape, showcasing the catalytic prowess of lattice oxygen atoms in orchestrating the transformation of water into oxygen gas. At its core, LOM elucidates the remarkable role played by oxygen atoms nestled within the crystalline lattice structure of catalyst materials. These lattice oxygen species exhibit a unique duality, seamlessly transitioning between different oxidation states by accepting and releasing O2– [57]. LOM orchestrates a precise sequence of events. Lattice oxygen atoms initiate the process by avidly accepting electrons and oxygen ions from the surrounding environment, initiating the formation of oxygen gas molecules [20,58]. This dynamic interplay positions these lattice oxygen atoms as catalytic intermediaries, channeling the conversion of water into oxygen gas [59]. Beyond a theoretical construct, LOM beckons innovation and drives the material design frontier, as we endeavor to propel energy conversion and storage technologies towards unprecedented sustainability and efficiency. 3.3 Research progress in new OER mechanism With the deepening of research, theoretical analysis and characterization techniques have developed rapidly. The current research trend in OER is to seek more accurate theoretical models to describe the OER catalytic mechanism to better explain the highly efficient catalytic activity observed experimentally. This trend emphasizes the need for a deeper understanding of the complexity of OER catalytic mechanisms and is committed to proposing multiple catalytic mechanisms using multiple comprehensive analysis methods to understand the nature of this key reaction more fully. Newly proposed mechanisms in recent years mainly focus on breaking the scale relationship between OH and OOH, achieving direct coupling of O–O and rapid release of triplet oxygen. The main representatives are OPM and OCM and their derived related mechanisms [60]. Different types of catalyst structures and their customized mechanisms are being actively studied. 3.3.1 Oxide path mechanism (OPM) Conventional AEM involves relatively high overpotentials due to limitation of the linear scaling relationship. In LOM, active lattice oxygen participates in OER and promote O–O coupling, while the resulting oxygen vacancy defects can cause the metal to detach from the catalyst surface to result in rapid degradation of the electrocatalyst. There are complex triggering conditions for LOM, such as the activation of lattice oxygen: the energy of the O 2p orbital must move up to near the Fermi level in order to overlap with the central d orbital of the metal (i.e., the covalent bond that strengthens the M–O bond), and therefore the redox energy of oxygen passing through the lattice. At the same time, many holes need to be constructed to destabilize the lattice oxygen atoms and enable O2 to be released. In 1956, Pennsylvania et al. [22] demonstrated the possibility of multiple O–O direct coupling paths (including Electrochemical oxide path, Hydrogen peroxide path, Metal Peroxide path) in the anodization of water through kinetic analysis. The OPM has received only limited attention since its introduction. With the deepening of research, understanding and studying microscopic catalytic mechanisms at the molecular level has become a reality. More and more studies have discovered the advantages of the OPM mechanism and are committed to directional design of catalysts based on OPM. This is because this mechanism can directly couple O–O radicals to break the linear limitations of AEM without generating oxygen vacancy defects and additional reaction intermediates, such as *OOH (Fig. 8(a) ) [61]. In OPM, in the absence of lattice oxygen, active metal sites at appropriate locations work together to dissociate water and trigger *O radical coupling to produce O2. However, compared with AEM and LOM, OPM has stricter requirements on the geometric configuration of metal active sites [62]. Symmetric bimetallic sites with appropriate atomic distances are expected to facilitate coupling of O–O radicals with low energy barriers. Recently, Lee et al. [26] reported a crystalline α-MnO2 nanofiber-supported Ru electrocatalyst (Ru/MnO2) that satisfies OPM design rules (Fig. 8(b)). The catalyst was prepared by a one-step cation exchange method in which Ru atoms replace surface Mn atoms. Therefore, the positions of Ru atoms follow the periodic arrangement of Mn sites in α-MnO2 crystals, forming small and regularly arranged Ru ensembles. During OER process, cation exchange reactions also occur in situ, which not only triggers the reconstruction of small Ru ensembles into bulk Ru atomic arrays, but also avoids catalyst deactivation caused by metal leaching. The Ru atomic array consists of symmetric Ru sites, which is very conducive to OPM-type OER. The distance between Ru-Ru atoms in Ru/MnO2 (2.9 Å) is shorter than the distance between Ru-Ru atoms in RuO2 (3.1 Å), which is beneficial to the coupling of O-O radicals (Fig. 8(c)). The overpotential of Ru/MnO2 (12Ru/MnO2) with 11.6 wt% Ru loading under acidic conditions is only 161 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Extensive ex-situ and operando measurements of changes in Ru/MnO2 reaction intermediates and surface chemical characteristics indicate that OER follows OPM mechanism without formation of *OOH (Figs. 8(d) and (e)). In addition, DFT and operando differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) confirm that OER proceeds through OPM mechanism when Ru/MnO2 is used as a water oxidation electrocatalyst. Recently, Zhang et al. [30] studied OPM from the perspective of spin polarization, and proposed a Co-Fe dual-site segmentally synergistic mechanism (DSSM) for single-domain ferromagnetic catalyst CoFeS x nanoclusters (CFS-ACs/CNT) (Figs. 8(f) and (g)). It was found that low-spin Co3+ (L.S, t2g 6eg 0) provides the strong OH* adsorption energy, while medium-spin Fe3+ (M.S, t2g 4eg 1) exhibits strong O* adsorption. These two positions cooperate to produce the Co–O–O–Fe intermediate, thereby accelerating the release of triplet oxygen (Fig. 8(h)). Empirical studies and computational analyses have revealed that ferromagnetic carbon-iron single-atom catalysts (CFSACs) with dimensions in the range of 1.5 to 3 nm behave as single-domain ferromagnetic entities. This characteristic endows the catalysts with an intrinsic electric field that facilitates the polarization of the spin states of critical oxygen intermediates during the water oxidation process. The induced spin polarization leads to a parallel alignment of spins, which in turn diminishes the energy barrier for the formation of O-O coupling intermediates. This reduction in the formation barrier is instrumental in enhancing the direct desorption of triplet oxygen, thereby optimizing the catalytic pathway for water oxidation. 3.3.2 oxo-oxo coupling mechanism (OCM) The OCM is a recently proposed OER mechanism based on SACs. Unlike OPM and LOM, which require a high-density metal oxide system, OCM emphasizes the direct coupling of O*-O* radicals on a single metal site of SACs to achieve oxygen evolution. Using DFT methods, Pacchioni et al. [29] studied a set of 30 SACs made of 10 metal atoms (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Pd and Pt) anchored in three widely used 2D carbon-based materials, including graphene, nitrogen-doped graphene and carbon nitride. After analyzing all configurations, it was found that the most favorable reaction path involved direct coupling of oxygen. More stable intermediates such as M(OH)2, M(O)(OH), M(O)2 and M(O2) tend to be formed at single atom sites (Fig. 9(a) ). Therefore, OCM shares conceptual similarities with LOM and OPM by enabling the direct coupling of O-O radicals, bypassing high-energy intermediates like OOH* to facilitate efficient oxygen release and reduce the reaction energy barrier. Unlike traditional 3D oxides, which limit *O–*O bond formation to the surface due to low bulk flexibility, the 2D structure of graphene-based supports provides sufficient structural adaptability for radical coupling. This flexibility breaks conventional scaling relationships, offering a pathway to overcome kinetic bottlenecks. Additionally, single-atom catalysts with configurations akin to graphene enhance structural flexibility, further optimizing the coupling of *O-*O. Additionally, dual-atom catalysts (DACs) featuring adjacent atomic metal sites provide an ideal platform to investigate the fundamental chemistry and structural implications of OCM. These DAC systems allow for synergistic interactions between two distinct catalytic centers, further optimizing OER efficiency by modulating adsorption energies and electron transfer dynamics. Further, Sun et al. [27] further proposed an OCM pathway for dual-metallic atoms as catalytic sites based on previous studies (Fig. 9(b)). They also used large-scale DFT to explore the feasibility of the *O-*O coupling mechanism by improving the M’M of the catalytic performance of Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu heteronuclear diatomic catalysts supported on N-doped graphene. Based on the constructed activity map, rationally designed descriptors can be obtained to predict homonuclear catalysts. Seven heteronuclear and four homonuclear diatomic catalysts showed high activity, exceeding the minimum theoretical overpotential. The chemical and structural origins that favor the *O-*O coupling mechanism and thereby enhance reactivity are revealed. The OER activity of 82 heteronuclear carbon-supported metal diatomic clusters (M¢M@NC) was screened through pre-selected OCM pathways, and the activity map drawn showed that this non-traditional mechanism can improve OER activity, especially NiPd@NC (η = 0.06 V), CuPd@NC (η = 0.07 V) and CuPt@NC (η = 0.08 V) (Figs. 9(c) and (d)). Subsequent analysis revealed that the enhanced activity can be ascribed to the synergy between bimetallic active sites capable of modifying the adsorption of crucial oxygen-containing intermediates (*OH, *OH-*OH, *OH-*O, and *O2). This circumvents the restriction imposed by the proportional relationship associated with the key oxygen-containing intermediates in AEM, thereby surpassing the lowest theoretical overpotential bottleneck of 0.37 V. And the descriptor ΔG(*OH-*OH) obtained through rational design can be used to predict the reactivity (Figs. 9(e) and (f)). 3.3.3 intramolecular oxygen coupling mechanism (IMOC) Nocera et al. [24] studied binuclear cobalt complexes and combined DEMS with oxygen isotopes to reveal the important role of edge sites of cobalt oxide water oxidation catalysts (Co-OECs) in OER. The catalytic process they proposed includes a series of proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) oxidation steps (Fig. 10(a) ). The catalyst was initially deposited from solution in the form of Co(III). Some Co(IV) centers are located at the edges of Co-OEC clusters, showing significant Co(III) oxygen radical characteristics. The formation of O–O bonds can be achieved through two main mechanisms: one is that two oxygen radicals directly combine to form a bridging peroxo intermediate (i.e., IMOC) (Fig. 10(b)); the other is that the oxygen radical extracts a hydrogen atom from a water molecule to form a hydroperoxo intermediate (i.e., WNA) (Fig. 10(c)). In addition, recent research on the transformation of IMOC and WMC mechanisms will be introduced in the next chapter. 3.4 Other unique mechanisms In addition to the above mechanisms, recent studies have also proposed some unique catalytic mechanisms for some specific catalytic structures. Piccinin et al. [31] obtained an atomic-level understanding of the multi-hole mechanism of OER on α-Fe2O3 by combining pulse voltammetry, full solid/liquid interface DFT calculations and macrodynamic modeling (Fig. 11 ). It was found that holes accumulate at the solid/liquid interface through a single-electron proton-coupled electron transfer PCET step, leading to the formation of Fe-oxo groups with characteristics intermediate between Fe(III)-oxyl and Fe(IV)-oxo. In alkaline environments, formation of O–O bond occurs via facile oxidation of solvent hydroxide ions to form surface-bound superoxide intermediates. This basic step requires the presence of three nearby Fe-oxo/oxy groups. However, once these groups are present, the activation energy is weakly dependent on their concentration, resulting in a power-law dependence of the OER rate on the surface hole concentration. Wu et al. [63] proposed a self-cycling electrochemical-thermal OER mechanism (SET-OER) as a new approach for efficient high-temperature OER (Fig. 12(a) ). SET-OER couples two consecutive reactions on the anode: (i) single-electron electrochemical oxidation of Ni(OH)2 to generate NiOOH; (ii) in-situ thermal decomposition of NiOOH to release O2 and recover Ni(OH)2 (Fig. 12(b)). DFT and in-situ Raman shows that the SET-OER pathway on NiOOH (100) is the dominant reaction mechanism at 120 °C (Fig. 12(c)). It only needs a low potential of 1.25 V at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 to achieve stable and efficient operation of the water oxidation reaction at 120 °C. Complementing this, Gan et al. [65] recently proposed anodic-cathodic sequential OER (ACS-OER) mechanism also highlights unconventional pathways for Ni-based OER catalysis, but under standard conditions (Fig. 12(d)). Unlike SET-OER, ACS-OER features a unique anodic-cathodic sequential mechanism where Ni(OH)₂ undergoes electrochemical oxidation to NiOO–, followed by a reduction back to Ni(OH)₂ during O₂ release. This process underscores the influence of lattice oxygen redox dynamics, transitioning the RDS to oxygen release instead of conventional intermediate formation. Furthermore, a concept known as the bifunctional mechanism has recently emerged. This mechanism entails the cooperation of two catalytic sites, typically involving two different metal ions, working synergistically [61]. One site contributes the electrophilic M=O species, while the other site provides the hydrogen atom acceptor. Although the direct nucleophilic attack of OH* on M=O to form the M-OOH intermediate is energetically unfavorable, the collaborative transfer of hydrogen atoms to nearby acceptors significantly lowers the energy barrier. Hu et al. [64] finally confirmed the existence of this mechanism through operando Raman spectroscopy and dynamic electrochemical analysis of FeOOH-NiOOH and NiFe LDH. The spectroscopic and kinetic data offer support for two distinct mechanisms in these catalysts. FeOOH-NiOOH operates through a bifunctional mechanism, where the rate-determining step involves the coordinated attack of OH on Fe=O, leading to O-O bond formation and the transfer of hydrogen atoms to NiIII-O sites. In contrast, NiFe LDH follows the conventional mechanism involving four consecutive PCET steps. This study presents the initial experimental evidence for the bifunctional mechanism, which was previously supported only theoretically. In large-scale applications of OER, the advantages and challenges of different catalytic mechanisms must be carefully considered. The AEM is widely studied for its efficiency in oxygen adsorption and desorption, but its performance is limited by the scaling relations between intermediates like *OH and *O, which restrict oxygen release efficiency and cause surface deactivation. The LOM, which bypasses these scaling relations by using lattice-bound oxygen species, improves efficiency in catalysts such as transition metal (oxy)hydroxides. However, it faces stability issues due to lattice oxygen loss during prolonged cycling, which undermines catalyst durability. Future research should focus on improving lattice oxygen stability through optimized support structures or doping strategies. Mechanisms such as OPM and OCM show potential by directly coupling oxygen radicals *O-*O without the participation of lattice oxygen, bypassing high-energy intermediates such as *OOH. This mechanism benefits from a special catalytic structure that promotes efficient radical coupling and enhances reaction kinetics. However, OCM is still at the theoretical stage with limited experimental validation, and further research is needed on long-term stability. Finally, the reported studies on different OER mechanisms and their main research contents are summarized (Table 1 ). A hybrid approach combining these mechanisms could provide a promising solution. Future research should focus on monitoring dynamic shifts between mechanisms, improving catalyst stability, and developing scalable synthesis techniques to ensure consistent performance in real-world applications. 4 Transformation and coexistence of multiple mechanisms As researchers delve deeper into catalytic mechanisms, they encounter new and intricate challenges concerning the genesis and regulation of catalytic activity, as well as the interplay between catalytic structure and performance [73,74]. Concurrently, there is a growing realization that simplifying OER mechanism of a particular catalyst into a single pathway is inadequate for fully elucidating the multifaceted catalytic process. Instead, mounting evidence suggests that multiple OER mechanisms often coexist or transition during catalysis, necessitating a more comprehensive and adaptable understanding of catalytic mechanisms [52]. Consequently, a burgeoning research trend involves designing bespoke catalyst structures informed by the catalyst mechanism or investigating unconventional mechanisms in certain catalyst types [75]. The quest for descriptors elucidating the interplay between catalytic structure, activity, and mechanism is paramount in this endeavor. Traditional research paradigms have long held that various mechanisms function as isolated routes, while a solitary route may not adequately dissect the intricate catalytic mechanisms in OER. In AEM, the overpotential limits derived from linear relationships have significantly impeded the catalytic activity of OER in electrochemical energy conversion processes [76]. LOM tends to be triggered on oxygen-rich surfaces under in-situ conditions, but the specific geometric and electronic structures required for this mechanism. Firstly, the catalyst should possess high metal-oxygen covalency, which can be achieved through the high electronegativity of the metal or specific doping elements (such as Mo in MoNiFe (oxy)hydroxides) [77]. This covalency helps activate lattice oxygen and reduce the energy barrier for oxygen vacancy formation. Secondly, the electronic structure of the catalyst should allow the O 2p band center to be close to the Fermi level, as observed in AuSA-MnFeCoNiCu LDH, which enhances the activity of lattice oxygen. Additionally, the catalyst surface should be capable of forming oxygen vacancies, which can be filled by OH− during the OER process, thereby regenerating the active surface sites. Lastly, the geometric structure of the catalyst should facilitate the deprotonation of lattice oxygen and the release of O2, as seen in Ir-MnO2 through strain-induced adjustment of the Ir site’s adsorption behavior. These structural characteristics work together to enable the catalyst to effectively perform OER through the LOM mechanism, enhancing reaction efficiency and stability [78]. However, as research progresses, an increasing body of experimental evidence has demonstrated the limitations of solely relying on either AEM or LOM to accurately explain real catalytic processes [79]. Specifically, for common AEM catalysts, recent experimental advances in catalytic performance suggest that the actual OER activity may not always be consistent with the theoretical activity limit of 0.37 V derived from thermodynamic DFT calculations. This discrepancy suggests that the catalytic mechanism of OER in practice may involve additional complexity captured by the energy scaling relation, which may be affected by factors such as dynamic surface states, intermediate stability, and the local reaction environment, leading to the coexistence of multiple mechanisms in the transformation. Recently, Zhang et al. [81] significantly improved the activity of the cubic Y2−x Co x Ru2O7−δ (YCR) lattice by adding an appropriate amount of cobalt dopant (YCR molar ratio of 12.5%). The enhancement of OER reactivity may be related to co-induced charge redistribution, band gap reduction, increase of oxygen vacancy density and fast charge transfer capability. Studies have found that Co substitution can adjust the electronic environments of Ru and O, thereby essentially simultaneously reducing the theoretical overpotentials of the LOM and AEM paths. The contributions and coordination modes of different mechanisms during actual OER remain unclear. Liu and colleagues [38] investigated the interplay between AEM and LOM in OER. They used Co3O4 as model material and discovered a reconstructed (110) surface under reaction conditions. This surface exposed active sites as Co3+ 5f species. They explored 23 types of metal doping and found that early transition metal doping could improve the thermodynamics of lattice oxygen participation, while dual Zn-Cr doping could enhance O-O coupling (Fig. 13(a)-(c) ). Despite similar thermodynamics, AEM remained dominant on the reconstructed surface due to slow LOM kinetics. The OER activity volcano with all 23 dopants revealed that certain dopants, especially Zn-Cr dual doping, could thermodynamically prevent the formation of OOH* intermediates, lowering the theoretical OER overpotential. The study emphasized the need for moderate oxygen activity to prevent OOH* while preserving thermodynamic tendency of LOM. Some new research suggests that the coexistence of catalytic mechanisms might be dynamic, implying that transitions between mechanisms can occur during the reaction [34]. Such dynamic transitions could be attributed to the factors, such as structural changes on the catalyst’s surface, the formation of different intermediates, and alterations in reaction conditions. For example, Xue et al. [34] investigated a strain-stabilized non-stoichiometric nickel oxyhydroxide (NiOOH) nanobelt with alternating 4-coordinate and 6-coordinate nickel (Ni) edges (NR-NiOOH) which exhibited a switchable and optimized electron transfer pathway under illumination (Figs. 13(d)–(g)). They proposed a photo-induced OER process with a convertible metal and oxygen redox center, known as the coupled oxygen evolution mechanism (COM). This mechanism primarily involves three electon transfer processes: (1) photo-induced electron transfer from (M–O) to the dz orbital followed by the external circuit (oxygen oxidation), (2) electron transfer from d z 2 orbital to d z orbital, and (3) electron transfer from (O–O)2 coupled orbital to the external circuit (metal oxidation) (Fig. 13(g)). COM proceeds through optimized pathways, where deprotonation occurs at the metal site, and the O–O coupling process occurs at the oxygen site. Geometric changes result in alternating metal and oxygen features in the electronic states around the Fermi level throughout oxygen evolution process. Theoretical calculations confirmed the superiority of the COM route. To achieve COM, a non-overlapping region must emerge from the partial overlap between the d z 2 orbital and the a1g* band to facilitate photo-induced electron transfer from (M-O) to d z orbital. This electronic configuration is conducive to the universality of photo-induced electron transfer from (M-O) to d z in various structures like NiFe LDH, NiCrOOH, NiMnOOH, NiVOOH, NiCOOH, and NiCuOOH. Therefore, it is essential to adapt flexibly to this dynamism to gain a more accurate understanding of the nature of catalytic reactions. Recently, Li et al. [80] explored the catalytic mechanisms of Sr/Ir-based perovskite catalysts by employing cobalt doping and the dynamic dissolution of Co/Sr bimetallic ions. In situ experimental evidence demonstrated that the emergence of Co enhances the activation of surface lattice oxygen, which in turn fosters the creation of unsaturated IrO x species. Meanwhile, cobalt in the bulk state finely tunes the adsorption energy of these unsaturated IrO x species, effectively decreasing the overpotential required for the OER (Fig. 13(h)). However, DEMS findings suggest a relatively low extent of lattice oxygen release, implying that the catalytic process does not predominantly follow the LOM pathway (Fig. 13(i)). By combining in situ techniques, the authors have put forward a lattice oxygen-promoted adsorption mechanism (Fig. 13(j)). This mechanism begins with cobalt triggering the release of lattice oxygen, which subsequently leads to the formation of unsaturated IrO x . The emergence of these unsaturated IrO x species notably diminishes the overpotential associated with the adsorption mechanism, prompting a “switch” in OER mechanism. This process is characterized by its dynamic nature. If the adsorption mechanism is too rapid, it could result in the oxidation of unsaturated IrO x and the subsequent replenishment of oxygen. Meanwhile, saturated IrO x may continue to facilitate lattice oxygen release, establishing a dynamic and ongoing cycle. Furthermore, Seitz et al. [71] investigated the dynamic reconstruction of the catalyst surface under operating conditions on the surface of iridium oxide-based catalysts to clarify the role of subcrystalline structural patterns and demonstrated that Fe doping can improve iridium catalysts. The authors found that the amorphous IrO x species formed on the surface of SrIrO3 crystals during acidic water electrolysis are actually quasicrystal line structures with short-range and medium-range (7–9 Å) order. Advanced characterization techniques (including 4D-STEM to give the local electron pair distribution function ePDF, X-ray scattering pair distribution function xPDF, and EXAFS characterization) clearly explained that the highly active IrO x materials contain three types of structures formed by [IrO6] octahedral connections. In addition, the authors constructed a method to stabilize IrO x quasi crystalline nanoparticles (structures like the amorphous IrO x /SrIrO3 surface structure formed after the OER reaction), resulting in excellent OER catalytic activity, long-term stability, improved Ir utilization efficiency, and avoiding the use of bulk iridium crystal supports. The results indicate that sub crystalline IrO x materials can support highly active sites via both AEM and LOM pathways, and interestingly, the presence of Ir vacancies further enhances the LOM activity. The coexistence and switching of multiple mechanisms open promising avenues for enhancing OER performance, but it also highlights critical gaps in our understanding of these pathways. While studies demonstrate that even partial LOM engagement can significantly enhance catalytic activity by increasing active site density and bypassing high-energy intermediates, this enhancement is often material dependent. The structural stability challenges associated with excessive LOM activity, such as oxygen vacancy formation and potential catalyst degradation, remain a critical limitation. Current experimental methods also fall short in quantitatively distinguishing the contributions of AEM and LOM, particularly under dynamic operating conditions, which impedes precise mechanistic understanding. Future research should prioritize developing advanced operando techniques, such as in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and isotope-labeled studies, to directly probe the interplay between AEM and LOM during OER. Computational approaches, including machine learning-assisted calculations, can be harnessed to model complex catalytic systems and predict the optimal balance between AEM and LOM contributions. Furthermore, designing catalysts with tunable electronic and structural properties, such as strain-engineered oxides or dual-site configurations, could enable precise control over the dominant mechanism under various conditions. These efforts should also address long-term stability concerns, integrating operando monitoring of lattice oxygen dynamics with strategies to mitigate degradation. Evaluating existing research reveals an over-reliance on idealized models that often fail to capture the nuances of real-world operation, such as electrolyte effects or variable reaction environments. Future studies should bridge this gap by incorporating industrially relevant conditions into both experimental and computational frameworks, ensuring that the insights gained are translatable to practical applications. By addressing these challenges, researchers can unlock the full potential of synergistic multiple mechanisms pathways, paving the way for next-generation OER catalysts with superior efficiency and durability. 4.1 Endopathic factors of mechanism conversion In the high potential environment for OER, metal catalysts often undergo in-situ surface reconstruction [82,83]. This surface reconstruction provides a convenient way and a research breakthrough for the design of catalysts and the study of catalytic mechanisms [84]. Heteroatom doping, surface reconstruction (crystalline transformation or dynamic active sites), charge regulation, interface effects, etc. are common strategies to induce changes in OER catalytic mechanism [85]. The most used method to achieve mechanism transformation is doping, including doping of metals and heteroatoms [86]. The doping of metals can induce catalyst surface reconstruction, adjust bond lengths through electronic adjustment, create vacancies and defects to promote the conversion of reaction mechanism [87]. It was widely believed that doping would not cause the transformation of OER mechanism from AEM to LOM, and the enhancement of its activity was mainly attributed to the optimization of the binding energy of oxygen intermediates. However, most recent studies have overturned this inherent knowledge. More and more research results have indicated that heteroatom doping adjusts both the electronic structure and the electronic configuration of the metal and induces the changes of the catalytic mechanism [88]. This section summarizes the strategy of mechanism transformation from various aspects and tries to explore the endopathic factors of mechanism transformation (Fig. 14 ). 4.1.1 Surface reconstruction Only through collaborative thought of catalytic pathway dynamics and structure dynamics of catalysts can we truly explore the design principles of new advanced catalysts and improve their catalytic performance. Zhang et al. [89] studied the kinetics of Fe as a dopant which induced catalyst surface reconstruction and catalytic pathway evolution in spinel NiCo2O4 during the OER process. They found that partial Fe doping helps to accelerate the surface reconstruction of NiCo2O4 to Ni1–x Fe x Co2O4@NiOOH and thus precisely regulate the catalytic pathway from AEM to LOM (Fig. 15(a) ). For NiOOH on the NiCo2O4 surface, OER followed AEM with a Gibbs barrier of 0.795 eV for the rate-determining step (*O formation). For NiFeOOH on the Ni1-x Fe x Co2O4 surface, the pathway shifted to LOM, with *OH formation becoming the RDS and the overpotential decreasing to 0.438 eV. Fe doping significantly reduced the O–O coupling energy, resulting in activation of surface oxygen and improvement of catalytic performance by enabling direct O–O coupling and altering key intermediate steps. Interestingly, Hou et al. [72] reported that dynamic Cu evolution transforms the precatalyst into CoFeCuOOH by electrodeposition of CoFe LDH on Cu2S substrate (Fig. 15(b)). The integration of Cu significantly enhances as the covalency of the Co–O bonds, promotes electron transfer within the molecular structure to generate ligand vacancies, and enhances the propensity of lattice oxygen as active sites. In situ 18O isotope labeling combined with DEMS and theoretical calculations were used to reveal the catalytic mechanism. The study shows that the Cu2S/CoFeCuOOH catalyst favors the OVSM pathway of LOM. Chemical probing experiments using TMA+ confirmed the direct involvement of lattice oxygen and clarified the origin of oxygen in the generated O2. 4.1.2 Metal and non-metal doping Wang et al. [58] used different amounts of Zn2+ to replace Co in CoOOH as a model catalyst for OER (Fig. 16(a) ). It is found that the switch from AEM to LOM can be achieved only when two adjacent oxidized oxygen atoms are able to hybridize their oxygen holes without significantly sacrificing the metal-oxygen hybridization significantly. Among them, the most active catalyst, Zn0.2Co0.8OOH, has Zn-O2-Co-O2-Zn configuration. Raman spectroscopy and chemical probe analysis identified negative peroxide-like substances from LOM. In addition, the specific Zn-O2-Co-O2-Zn structure provides a balance between direct O–O coupling and oxygen vacancy refilling, maintaining the stability of the catalyst (Figs. 16(b), (c)). Coincidentally, Zhang et al. [90] successfully synthesized zinc-doped RuO2 nanowire arrays (py-RuO2:Zn) with excellent acidic OER performance through a simple pyrolysis method. The study found that the substitutional doping of zinc not only adjusted the morphology of the catalyst, but also produced many oxygen defects and low-priced Ru sites. Theoretical studies show that oxygen vacancy defects and Zn doping lead to weakened oxygen adsorbent binding in the active Ru center, resulting in moderate adsorption of *OH on Zn sites (Figs. 16(d)–(g)). The results confirmed that the OER pathway was transformed from the traditional AEM to the Ru-Zn dual-site OPM, thereby significantly improving the OER activity. At the same time, the OPM path avoids excessive oxidation of the OER metal sites, thereby protecting the active center, and the presence of Zn dopants and Vo defects stabilizes the structure of the RuO2 matrix. Hyeon et al. [91] designed a mild synthesis strategy to successfully dope metallic Al into RuO2 and RuIrO x for high-durability OER. Al doping can effectively adjust the valence electron structure of Ru–O hybrid orbitals, thereby regulating the adsorption energy of oxygen intermediates and promoting the formation of O–O bonds. The uniform introduction of Al on the catalyst surface can effectively improve the acidic OER kinetics of iridium-free and low-iridium catalysts. The high covalency of Ru–O bonds in RuO2-based catalysts can lead to significant ruthenium dissolution due to oxidation of lattice oxygen., Inhibiting the oxidation of lattice oxygen and establishing stable high-activity ruthenium sites within RuO2 presents a fresh approach to solve above problem. Wei et al. [92] introduced an interstitial Si-modified RuO2 catalyst that demonstrates exceptional activity and stability for OER in acidic media. By doping Si into RuO2 lattice, the adsorption strength of the *OOH intermediate at the active ruthenium sites is optimized, which in turn lowers the energy barrier of the rate-limiting step, enhancing the intrinsic activity of OER. Crucially, the introduction of Si, which is resistant to acid, into the interstitial sites of RuO2 forms a Si–O bond with high binding energy, thereby diminishing the covalency of the Ru–O bonds. This synergy between the acid-resistant Si, the robust Si–O interactions and the reduced covalency of the Ru–O bonds enables the interstitial Si-modified RuO2 catalyst to effectively inhibit LOM throughout the OER process, thereby exhibiting remarkable stability over time. In addition, metal doping often induces surface reconstruction in catalysts, leading to more intricate catalytic mechanisms. For instance, Wang et al. [93] investigated an evolved FeNiSe₂ variant, Ir₁@FeNiSe₂, which featured isolated Ir atoms dispersed on Fe sites through ion exchange between Ir and Fe. Ir₁@FeNiSe₂ underwent irreversible transformation into Ir₁@NiOOH, involving Fe leaching, Se–O exchange, and phase transitions. This substitution enhanced the O 2p band and strengthened metal-oxygen covalency, transitioning the OER mechanism from AEM to SMSM and ultimately to a DMSM pathway (Figs. 17(a) and (b) ). Computational validation using chemical probes and in situ DEMS confirmed these transformations (Fig. 17(c)). The doping of non-metallic heteroatoms can still promote the switching of OER mechanisms. He et al. [94] successfully revealed the transition of OER mechanism from AEM to LOM by inducing a significant enhancement of the OER activity of 1D NiFeO x through P doping (Fig. 18(a) ). The study found that after P doping, the Ni 3d orbital center energy decreased, while the O 2p orbital center energy increased slightly, causing the Ni 3d orbital energy band to overlap with the O 2p orbital. This overlap can significantly enhance metal-oxygen covalency, activate lattice oxygen, and thereby trigger the LOM pathway. DFT calculations and experimental results verify that P doping significantly enhances the energy band overlap of the Ni 3d orbital and O 2p orbital in NiOOH, thereby achieving the pathway transition from AEM to LOM (Figs. 18(b) and (c)). Impressively, this mechanistic transition was also observed on S-doped 1D NiFeO x . Therefore, this transformation may be a common phenomenon in heteroatom doped OER electrocatalysts. Xia et al. [96] constructed S heteroatom-doped nickel-iron-based hydroxide through a microbial corrosion strategy. The corrosion-formed Ni(Fe)OOH-FeSx electrode exhibits excellent OER activity in alkaline electrolytes. The synergistic effect between Ni(Fe)OOH and Fe-S may be responsible for the enhanced activity. Theoretical calculations show that the formation of *O on the Ni(Fe)OH-FeSx electrode is the RDS of the oxygen evolution, and the addition of Fe-S species will enhance the binding between Fe and active *O intermediates. To further understand the impact of S doping on the OER mechanism, Liu et al. [95] prepared a three-dimensional vertical nanosheet-like S-doped FeOOH structure on an intermediate frequency substrate through a simple and ultrafast method. Since both Fe and lattice oxygen in FeOOH have sufficient activation redox reaction activity, S doping greatly improves the intrinsic OER activity of FeOOH (Fig. 18(d)). Experimental results show that the activity is improved compared with similar catalysts without S doping. The DFT calculation results indicated that the LOM mechanism is an energy-favorable pathway for the S-FeOOH OER process (Figs. 18(e) and (f)). Chemical probe identification, in-situ FTIR spectroscopy and in-situ Raman spectroscopy combined with isotope experiments show that S doping causes the lattice oxygen in S-FeOOH to be fully activated and prompts the catalyst to participate in OER from AEM to LOM (Figs. 18(g)–(i)). 4.1.3 Vacancies and defects In the context of non-reconstructed catalyst surfaces, the interplay between AEM and LOM mechanisms has sparked considerable debate regarding their respective contributions to OER activity. Recent advances demonstrate that surface doping, even in the absence of significant surface reconstruction, can effectively modulate the catalytic mechanism by introducing vacancies and defects. Unlike surface reconstruction, which entails substantial atomic rearrangements, doping introduces heteroatoms near the surface that create localized changes in electronic structure, lattice strain, and bonding characteristics. These modifications can alter the energy landscape of OER intermediates, shifting the balance between AEM and LOM pathways [97]. For example, Ge et al. [78] induced LOM without surface structural reconstruction through a single-point Ir doping strategy in MnO2. Due to the carefully defined chelating environment of Ir, Ir-O covalency increased and lattice oxygen oxidation participated, which promoted the transformation of AEM to LOM. More importantly, the locally triggered LOM did not introduce structural evolution during the OER process. DEMS combined with DFT calculations confirmed that the enhanced hybridization between Ir and O was crucial for triggering the participation of lattice oxygen in OER and providing higher intrinsic activity. However, further in-depth discussion is still needed on the possibility of doping for the generation of vacancies and defects and their association with the OER mechanism. Recently Liu et al. [98] demonstrated that doping nanofibrous cobalt spinel with lanthanum (La) and manganese (Mn) can increase the oxidation state or charge density of the catalytic metal cation sites, creating strain and oxygen vacancies, which promote lattice oxygen activation and promote the LOM pathway. At the same time, the creation of oxygen vacancies and defects through controlled doping can fine-tune the active sites and enhance the adsorbate interactions that are critical for AEM. This delicate balance provides a way to induce a shift in the catalytic mechanism without the drastic structural reorganization associated with reconstruction. Surface doping thus becomes a versatile tool to optimize catalytic activity and stability. Alexandrov et al [99]. investigated the catalytic activity of RuO2 (110) and IrO2 (211) catalysts in the presence of transition metal (Ni, Co, Cr, Fe, and Mn) doping and/or structural defects using DFT for AEM and LOM. Their research demonstrates that structural defects in catalysts, such as Ru vacancies in Ni- and Co-doped RuO2, can facilitate LOM, competing with the conventional AEM pathway. Specifically, in Ni-doped RuO2, the coexistence of Ru vacancies and Ni doping synergistically enhances LOM. The insight is a key finding that helps explain the prevalent experimental observation of lattice oxygen participation in nanocrystalline RuO2-based materials. Furthermore, the research delineates distinct local electronic structures associated with AEM and LOM, highlighting a significant correlation between the O 2p band center and the OER overpotential (Fig. 19(a) ). This finding underscores the importance of understanding the interplay between electronic structure and catalytic activity. Li et al. [69] introduced a defect engineering strategy to construct MOF (NiFc’ x Fc1–x ) containing abundant unsaturated metal site defects by blending different ligands. These defects facilitated the structural transformation of MOF into metal hydroxide, enhancing OER catalytic activity. Compared to non-defective MOF (NiFc’), NiFc’ x Fc1–x was more readily converted into metal hydroxide and generated more oxygen vacancies, displaying superior OER catalytic activity. These findings emphasize that different OER mechanisms may compete or coexist under varying conditions and structural defects can facilitate mechanistic shifts in OER under specific circumstances. Liu et al. [100] introduced strongly electronegative F ions into the lattice oxygen vacancies on the surface of ZnCo2O4 to strengthen the hybridization between Co 3d and O 2p and convert OER from AEM to LOM path (Fig. 19(b)). More importantly, the introduction of F ions stabilizes the structure of the catalyst and locally activates LOM during the OER process without reconstructing the surface (Figs. 19(c) and (d)). The results show that compared with similar catalysts without F, the prepared ZnCo2O4–x F x /CNTs has higher inherent activity and stability. Approximately, Peng et al. [101] successfully manipulated position of Ru single atoms on Co3O4 surface by using the metal defect anchoring points of the carrier to regulate the spatial positioning of single Ru atoms. Ru atoms embedded in cationic vacancies reveal an optimized mechanism for activating the proton donor-acceptor function (PDAM), demonstrating a new single-atom catalytic pathway to circumvent the classic scaling relationship. Doping and vacancy often synergistically promote the transformation of OER mechanism. Wu et al. [102] report a synergistic strategy of Rh doping and surface oxygen vacancy to precisely regulate the OER pathway. The DFT results show that Rh-RuO2/G obtains activity through a more optimal reaction path of lattice oxygen-mediated mechanism-oxygen vacancy mechanism (LOM-OVSM) (Figs. 19(e)–(h)). Zheng et al. [77] introduced Au single atoms and oxygen vacancies into a high-entropy metal double hydroxide (AuSA-MnFeCoNiCu LDH). This modified LDH showed significantly high OER activity and long-term stability compared to MnFeCoNiCu LDH. Isotope-labeled mass spectrometry and in situ Raman spectroscopy revealed the transition of the OER mechanism from AEM to LOM. DFT calculations disclosed that the synergy between Au single atoms and oxygen vacancies enhanced the O 2p orbital, weakened metal-oxygen bonds, activated lattice oxygen, reduced the energy barrier for LOM (Figs. 19(i)–(k)). 4.1.4 Interface engineering Interface engineering techniques can substantially promote the OER mechanism switching of catalysts [103,104]. For example, strategies involving support enhancement aim to optimize the support or substrate of catalysts, by tuning the electronic properties of the support to achieve the desired OER mechanism. Cho et al. [105] used zirconium oxide nitride (Zr2ON2) nanoparticles as carrier for the IrO x /Zr2ON2 to obtain high catalytic activity. A total of 2.14 e- is transferred from Zr2ON2 to IrO x surface to reduce IrO x and activate the Ir-O bond (Fig. 20(a) ). DFT calculations of isolated IrO x NPs and fully oxidized IrO x / Zr2ON2 on the surface illuminated that the reaction pathway changed from the traditional AEM on IrO x NPs to LOM pathway on IrO x /Zr2ON2 due to tensile strain and charge transfer (Figs. 20(b) and (c)). The theoretical potential of IrO x /Zr2ON2 is much lower than that of IrO x NP. Kim et al. [106] applied DFT calculations in conjunction with machine learning (ML)-based descriptors to investigate various combinations of single atoms on MXene surfaces. They systematically studied all feasible active sites to assess their stability, catalytic activity, and electronic properties relative to surface characteristics. The investigation specifically examined the behavior of SACs at two unique sites: SAC1, where atoms are stably lodged in hollow sites on the outer oxygen layer, and SAC2, where atoms reside on the displaced subsurface metal layer (Fig. 20(d)). Their research revealed that surface electronic modifications can induce shifts from the conventional AEM on SAC1 to LOM on SAC2 (Figs. 20(e), (f)). Recently, Peng et al. [66] developed a strategy to modulate the Ru-O-Ti interface by constructing adjustable supports to stabilize high-valence Ru nanoparticles. By engineering the interaction between Ru and Ti₄O₇, they achieved an optimal metal-support interaction. This moderation induced slight electronic enrichment at Ru sites, effectively suppressing the LOM pathway while enhancing the AEM mechanism via stabilized Ti-O-Ru units (Fig. 20(g)). This balance between activity and stability highlights the significant role of interface engineering in tailoring OER mechanisms and improving catalyst performance. These findings underscore the multifaceted role of surface engineering in tailoring catalytic behavior and offer valuable insights for the design and optimization of OER catalysts. In summary, the emerging trends in OER research emphasize the adoption of a more comprehensive perspective to understand catalytic mechanisms, including the coexistence and transition of different mechanisms. This holistic research approach contributes to a more comprehensive understanding of the nature of OER, providing a more accurate theoretical foundation for the development of efficient catalysts and clean energy technologies. In future, greater attention should be paid to the complexity and diversity of catalytic mechanisms to better address the challenges in this crucial field. 4.1.5 Others factors In addition to the conventional factors that induce mechanism transformation mentioned above, recent studies have shown that changes in hydroxyl coverage and applied potential in some catalyst structures can also promote mechanism transformation. For example, Jiao et al. [107] introduced Lewis acid sites (Cr) to construct Cr0.6Ru0.4O2 solid solution electrocatalysts, which have the characteristics of short Ru-Cr distance and strong affinity for OH–. By increasing the *OH coverage of the site and shortening the double site distance, *O radical formation and O-O radical coupling are promoted, thereby inhibiting the LOM mechanism and realizing the transformation of AEM to OPM pathway (Fig. 21(a) ), which has been verified by in situ experiments and theoretical calculations. Wang et al.
